result.execSummary:
The defendant Jason Alan Tacheny was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Jason Alan Tacheny is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Jason Alan Tacheny was found guilty of Violate/Harassment Restraining Order, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 813.125(7).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
1) The defendant must provide DNA and pay the surcharge; the analysis may be expunged upon application to the Department of Justice. All payments are ordered to be paid to the BURNETT COUNTY CLERK OF COURT'S OFFICE.  
2) The defendant has thirty (30) days to make payment of any amount ordered unless other arrangements are made with the Clerk of Court's office. Make checks or money orders payable to "BURNETT COUNTY" and send to: Burnett County Clerk of Court, 7410 Cty. Rd. K,  #115, Siren, WI 54872.    
Payments may be made either in person, by mail, or online either through wicourts.gov or through paygov.us. (subject to each website's processing fees). 
3) If the defendant pays $200 DNA surcharge in full and obtains a valid driver's license by the end of April, 2023, the remaining court costs will be waived.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Jason Alan Tacheny

records.addlTxt: Note from def/jail- DNA on file.
JOC and PP forms returned

9:09 AM Defendant Jason Alan Tacheny in court.  Attorney Daniel James Chapman in court for Jason Alan Tacheny.  Prosecuting attorney Kevin Thomas Schmidt in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Case is on for Plea/Sentencing Hearing.  Agreement is recited by Attorney Chapman: def pleading G to Ct 2: violate restraining order; DRI remainder, joint rec of 20 days jail (time-served) and court costs.  State moves to dismiss Count 1 outright- makes record; Court dismisses Count 1 outright.  Court asks def if they understand the agreement.  Def does.  Court reviews Def's constitutional rights.  Def understands that def is waiving those rights by entering into agreement today.  Court asks Def if they understand Court is not bound by agreement, and could order maximum penalties.  Def understands.  Court asks for plea. 
 Def enters a plea of Guilty.  Court finds def is making plea knowingly, intelligently and voluntarily.  Court finds a factual basis to accept the plea.  Court finds defendant guilty of Count 2 and orders a JOC; Count 3 DRI, Count 1 dismissed outright.  Victim appears, gives statement.  DA asks Court to accept agreement.  Defense attorney asks Court to accept agreement, notes def has served 23 days jail in this matter.  Def makes a statement to the Court.  
Court orders:
20 days jail (time served) 20 days jail credit; $443 court costs- $25/month minimum.  If def is able to pay off the $200 DNA surcharge and get DL by April and provides proof, will waive the remaining costs.
Appeal rights provided.  Fingerprints and DNA to be provided to the Sheriff before leaving the building.

Bond to cover Burnett County Cases 21CF149 and 22CF178.  No contact with the victim or their residence.  The defendant shall maintain absolute sobriety.  Subject to random testing of breath, blood or urine by any law enforcement or corrections officer upon arrest or reasonable suspicion.

10:57 AM Defendant Jason Alan Tacheny appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Daniel James Chapman in court for Jason Alan Tacheny.  Prosecuting attorney Kevin Thomas Schmidt in court for the State of Wisconsin. Case set for motion hearing on bond motion.  Atty Chapman argues for bond modification.  Atty Schmidt not objecting to a post-able amount of cash.  Def states he cannot post any cash.  Def makes statement regarding FTA.  Court addresses defendant.  Chapman states a resolution is likely- misdemeanor offer.  Court denies bond modification.  Atty Chapman makes statement.  VR coordinator notes victim rights issues w/ 9/29 date proposed.  Court amends bond to signature with same conditions.
Plea/sentencing hearing scheduled for October 20, 2022 at 09:00 am.
Plea/sentencing hearing on October 20, 2022 at 09:00 am.
Motion hearing on September 26, 2022 at 10:30 am.
Status conference on September 26, 2022 at 10:30 am.
Only judge may quash this warrant unless the cash bond is posted in full.

2:37 PM Prosecuting attorney Kevin Thomas Schmidt in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Jason Alan Tacheny not in court.  Attorney Daniel James Chapman in court for Jason Alan Tacheny. Def fails to appear.  Court reviews for notice.  State requests warrant.  Atty Chapman stands mute.  Court orders warrant, $250, only judge may quash.

2:11 PM Prosecuting attorney James Jay Rennicke Esq in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Jason Alan Tacheny appeared by video, in custody, appearing from Barron County jail.  Case on for initial appearance, no PD yet appointed, but def eligible.  Discussion of bond.  Discussion of options- adjournment, proceeding, etc.  Case proceeds to Initial Appearance.  Defendant acknowledges receipt of complaint, requests reading.  Formal reading of complaint.  Court informs Defendant of charges, possible penalties and rights.  Def updates on residence- not sure where he'd reside if released, but would like a bond modification so he can be released.  State agrees to signature bond with no contacts.
